Styles

Styles allow you to change the basic look of MineDroid widgets.

Creating a style

Styles are located under 'assets/{modname}/styles' directory. Every style should be stored as a separate XML file.

Style contents

Style XML file should have a root tag named 'style'. That root tag can have a 'parent' attribute, which relates to a style that this file extends.

Style tag can has one or more 'item' tags, which define values for attributes of element to which the style should be applied.

Example style: view.xml

    <Style xmlns="http://onkiup.com/minecraft/xml">
        <item name="padding">10</item>
    </Style>

Themes

Themes are styles that group other styles and define which styles should be used for MineDroid views

Example theme

    <Style xmlns="http://onkiup.com/minecraft/xml">
        <item name="view">@minedroid:style/view.xml</item>
    </Style>

Views in theme

There is several theme items that you can define with your theme:

  • view — defines a style for any View and it's children
  • text — defines a style for any text drawable
  • text_view — defines a style for any TextView
  • content_view — defines a style for any ContentView and it's children
  • button — defines a style for all buttons
  • scroll_view — defines a style for ScrollView
  • overlay — defines a style for all windows (Overlays)
  • group_view — defines a style for any GroupView and views, derived from that class
  • list_view
  • linear_layout
  • relative_layout

Applying a theme

To apply a theme for your plugin, call MineDroid.setTheme method:

    MineDroid.setTheme(R.style.my_theme);

Applying style to a view

To apply a style to your view, use 'style' attribute on your XML layout:

    <TextView style="@style/my_textview"/>
